Comment: It's something I've thought about a bit. If you look at America, we've embraced false or differing realities since our inception. We created a supposedly free country, but it was still based around slavery. Then we went along with false understandings of issues like race or about how the South's fight in the Civil War was actually virtuous or just. We've kind of had two different realities in the country at least since the Civil War, two different histories of the nation which are starkly at odds. We still have memorials and commemorations for a regime which tried to maintain a strict order of slavery and racial discrimination.  This also isn't the first time media has been so divided. It used to be newspapers were completely based on political leanings. You'd mostly read and stick to the paper which subscribed to your political party or beliefs, and often the papers would perpetuate completely false or made up stories just to rile up their readers. This sometimes led to violence or even wars overseas based on tenuous or wrong information.  I do wonder what the exact distinction is in our current time. Is it this just the continuation or culmination of conflicts we've been having since the country was founded? Is it amplified because of recent media trends? Are the different realities now even farther apart than before? It's something worth a lot of deep thinking.
